post_title: [WIKI] Visiting Prague for the first time? Read this first!

comments.author: Lord_Lucan7
comments.body:
EAT

[https://meeltime.com/] (https://meeltime.com/) is the best website to find food near you, anywhere in Czech Republic!

Specifically though /u/secret_spy_operation made this awesome list:

	‚Ä¢	Cukrar Skala- best pistachio ice cream
	‚Ä¢	Cr√®me de la Cr√®me - best every other flavor of ice cream. Go to the Vinohrady location to avoid lines. 
	‚Ä¢	U Kroka - good traditional food
	‚Ä¢	El Camino Tapas Restaurant 
	‚Ä¢	Kavarna co hleda jmeno- breakfast/brunch
	‚Ä¢	Sia - Asian fusion (beautiful interior)
	‚Ä¢	Le Caveau Pekarna- bakery w/ amazing baguettes
	‚Ä¢	Mirabelle - French grocer to buy wine and cheese to go with your baguettes
	‚Ä¢	Venue - brunch
	‚Ä¢	Zona Bistro - sandwiches
	‚Ä¢	Benjamin - fine dining
	‚Ä¢	Field - Michelin starred $$$$
	‚Ä¢	Kantyna - meat
	‚Ä¢	Blue Vegan pig Shop - vegan donuts
	‚Ä¢	Spojka Karlin - European food? Idk
	‚Ä¢	Luka Lu - Balkan food
	‚Ä¢	Bulka Burger Bar 
	‚Ä¢	Kro Kitchen - chicken
	‚Ä¢	Etapa - vegetarian brunch
	‚Ä¢	Bruxx - Belgian
	‚Ä¢	Eaternia - hipster vegan ‚Äî food is hit or miss, but I like the hipster/punk crowd 
	‚Ä¢	Satsang - vegetarian 
	‚Ä¢	Shromazdiste - vegan
	‚Ä¢	La Botegga Linka/Bistroteka - Italian, also good eggs Benedict for breakfast 
	‚Ä¢	Oh Deer Bakery
	‚Ä¢	Artic Bakehouse 
	‚Ä¢	The Italians Wine Food
	‚Ä¢	Lokal - Czech restaurant chain ‚Äî reliable with great Pilsner
	‚Ä¢	Real Meat Society - Burgers
	‚Ä¢	Hillbilly - Burgers
	‚Ä¢	San Carlo Dittrichova - pizza
	‚Ä¢	Le Degustation - Michelin starred $$
	‚Ä¢	Cafe Savoy - good breakfast/decent dinner 
	‚Ä¢	Miska Ramen
	‚Ä¢	Restaurant Tiskarna - Czech 
	‚Ä¢	Big Smokers - bbq 
	‚Ä¢	Kohoutek - grilled chicken
	‚Ä¢	Kung Fu Pure Chinese Pasta - dumplings
	‚Ä¢	Layla - Lebanese 
	‚Ä¢	Chuan Wang Fu - Chinese 
	‚Ä¢	Eska Restaurant and Bakery
	‚Ä¢	Mr HoTDoG 
	‚Ä¢	Gemuse Corner Kebab
	‚Ä¢	Kin & K Bakery - coffee + pastries (vegan options too)
	‚Ä¢	Mazelab.coffee
	‚Ä¢	25,2 rpm - coffee 
	‚Ä¢	Typhoon Coffee
	‚Ä¢	Format Coffee
	‚Ä¢	Vnitroblock - coffee
	‚Ä¢	Botanica Coffee Truck - inside an amazing little garden
	‚Ä¢	La Boheme Cafe - coffee


Drink

	‚Ä¢	La Cave D‚ÄôAdrien - wine bar on a roundabout ‚Äî this roundabout is my favorite area in Prague when the weather is nice. It looks/feels like France.
	‚Ä¢	Kasarna Karlin - outdoor area and great place to drink in the afternoon. Sometimes has events.
	‚Ä¢	Ellise- cocktail bar 
	‚Ä¢	OSSEGG - beer/brewery
	‚Ä¢	Burza #4 outside bar
	‚Ä¢	Poco - chill hip bar
	‚Ä¢	Ankali - Berlin style club (dark and moody)
	‚Ä¢	Naplavka - riverside with bars and bars on boats - go here for sunset or when the weather is nice
	‚Ä¢	Stalin - area in Letna park that usually has things going on during Friday/Saturday nights
	‚Ä¢	Ferme
	‚Ä¢	Cafe Kamzik
	‚Ä¢	Miminoo- place to drink/eat under zizkov tower
	‚Ä¢	Beer geek
	‚Ä¢	Strahov Monastary Brewery - beer
	‚Ä¢	Champagneria
	‚Ä¢	Prosekarna Vinohradska
	‚Ä¢	Winebar 0,75 [Sedmiƒçka]
	‚Ä¢	Manesova Bar and Books - cocktails
	‚Ä¢	Scout Institute - hidden local bar next to old town square. Go up the stairs one floor
	‚Ä¢	Boudoir Bar - gay/hipster bar w/ mixed crowd. 
	‚Ä¢	NoD
	‚Ä¢	Groove Bar - trendy
	‚Ä¢	Moon Club - trendy 
	‚Ä¢	Dva Kohouti - brewery 
	‚Ä¢	Valhalla Beer Club
	‚Ä¢	Parlour - cocktails 
	‚Ä¢	Bar Pilotu - cocktails (best Bloody Mary in the city)
	‚Ä¢	Monkey Bar - really cute bar with a fabulous little garden 
	‚Ä¢	Bar Bohuzel - punk/metal bar 
	‚Ä¢	Bullerbyn - comfy/homely bar/cafe
	‚Ä¢	Electric Sheep Book Bar 

Shopping

	‚Ä¢	Fifty-fifty - thrift store
	‚Ä¢	Fashion Shop Parazit - hipster/interesting clothing store
	‚Ä¢	Artiseme- houseware/decorations
	‚Ä¢	Kulmal hilda - women‚Äôs thrift store
	‚Ä¢	Pour pour - women‚Äôs clothing
	‚Ä¢	NILAstore - interior decor and women‚Äôs clothes 
	‚Ä¢	Harddecore 
	‚Ä¢	Leeda - women‚Äôs clothing 
	‚Ä¢	SmetanaQ Showroom - local designer‚Äôs clothing/jewelry 
	‚Ä¢	Kvartyr - clothing
	‚Ä¢	Book Therapy 
	‚Ä¢	Xao (illustrated books)
	‚Ä¢	Ingredients - unique/luxury fragrance shop
	‚Ä¢	Pop Up Stories - home goods/women‚Äôs clothing
	‚Ä¢	ONES Concept Store - home goods 

Sites

	‚Ä¢	üëÅ = nice view and great for sunsets
	‚Ä¢	Prague 1/Old town square- historic part of Prague. Just get lost walking around. Food and drink are overpriced
	‚Ä¢	Letna - old houses and embassies plus beer garden overlooking the river
	‚Ä¢	Riegrovy sady - park overlooking the city + beer garden in the middle üëÅ
	‚Ä¢	Wenceslas Square
	‚Ä¢	National Museum 
	‚Ä¢	Museum of Communism
	‚Ä¢	Kunsthalle Museum 
	‚Ä¢	Museum of Decorative Arts 
	‚Ä¢	Rudolfinum- free art gallery 
	‚Ä¢	Dox Centre for Contemporary Art
	‚Ä¢	Charles Bridge
	‚Ä¢	Kampa - weird baby statues
	‚Ä¢	Zizkov TV tower - go up for a drink üëÅ
	‚Ä¢	Dancing house
	‚Ä¢	Vysehrad park üëÅ
	‚Ä¢	Grebovka Park
	‚Ä¢	Viktov Monument - giant statue and nice views. I think the museum is all in Czech though.  üëÅ
	‚Ä¢	Vrtba Gardens
	‚Ä¢	Prague Castle
	‚Ä¢	Waldstein Garden
	‚Ä¢	Stromovka park - beautiful to walk around if you‚Äôre in the area
	‚Ä¢	Franz Kafka head
	‚Ä¢	Lennon Wall - an unimpressive graffiti wall that‚Äôs a tourist attraction for some reason.
	‚Ä¢	Petrin - tower with nice park below it - take the funicular up to the top üëÅ
	‚Ä¢	Trojsky Zamek
	‚Ä¢	Divorka Sarka (hiking and trails)
	‚Ä¢	Chemistry Gallery - Art Gallery  
	‚Ä¢	Hidden Gallery - Art Gallery
	‚Ä¢	Bold Gallery - Art Gallery
	‚Ä¢	Vaclav Spala - Art Gallery 
	‚Ä¢	Theater Royal burlesque show

Download the app PID Litacka- buy a weekly pass or whatever for public transport. Otherwise you‚Äôll need a paper ticket, and that‚Äôs annoying. It‚Äôs very easy to get around here. Trams are the best. Subways are great. I almost never use buses.

Download the Rekola app if you want to rent bikes (I think there are several companies, but Rikola are the pink ones)

A beer cost between 40-60czk. You are in a tourist trap if you‚Äôre paying more.

You should tip ~10% at restaurants. They usually won‚Äôt ask you if you want to tip, nor will they have a place to leave a tip afterwards. You need to tell the server you want to add the tip BEFORE you pay.

Everyone uses contactless cards here. People will look at you crazy if you don‚Äôt have one.  Use Apple Pay or Google Pay to avoid awkwardness if your card doesn‚Äôt support contactless.

Not all restaurants/bars take cards. It‚Äôs a good idea to carry a bit of cash on you.

Uber works here. I also suggest downloading Bolt. It‚Äôs usually cheaper than Uber (but the same thing)

There are almost no free public restrooms. Be prepared to pay approximately 10-20czk. Some places take cards (contactless), but not always. The exceptions are Palladium and OC Novy Smichov (both shopping malls with free/clean toilets).

Unfortunately I don‚Äôt have a lot of Czech restaurant recommendations. But try to eat these things at a Czech restaurant. They are usually really good:

	‚Ä¢	Steak tartar
	‚Ä¢	Svickova
	‚Ä¢	Roasted duck
	‚Ä¢	Kolache
	‚Ä¢	Koleno (huge roasted pork knee)
	‚Ä¢	Kulajda (mushroom soup)

Day Trips/Additional Places

	‚Ä¢	Kutna Hora Ossuary (day trip only)- bone ossuary (amazing)
	‚Ä¢	Karlovy Vary
	‚Ä¢	Brno
	‚Ä¢	Cesky Krumlov (small but very beautiful, but kind of far and maybe not worth it if limited on time)
	‚Ä¢	Zlute Lazne (private swimming area)
	‚Ä¢	Pruhonice chateau/park (about an hour outside of Prague ‚Äî really beautiful)
	‚Ä¢	Karlstejn Castle

comments.author: StrangePotential1314
comments.body:
Main key to enjoy Prague. Go to restaurants that employ male waiters. 

Also if servants are rude simply tell them directly they must serve you. If they continue to be rude pay nothing and leave.

comments.author: WiseCookie69
comments.body: Another thing that comes up frequently here: If Airbnb / STR hosts ask you for your personal information and ID / passport number, it's because they have to provide this information to the city / police, in the same way as a hotel would have to do. It's a legitimate request.

I read on livingprague.com that the the Main Train station, Hlavni Nadrazi is a magnet for drug dealers and users and sitting in the grass is a risk for pick pocketing.  
This is the only place I‚Äôve read something like this.  As a solo female will I be Ok going through the park to catch the #15 Tram on Bolzanova to get to Malostranske Namesti at around 8:15-8:30am?

comments.author: xxxvodnikxxx
comments.body:
Kolache is actually "Kol√°**ƒç**e" - but yes, "ƒç" spoken sounds as "ch"

places to visit at  Prague - secret gems - **passages in city center**

(eg my favourite *Veceslav's square => ≈†tƒõp√°nsk√°* street => Pal√°c *Lucerna* (passage) => straight throught => *cross Vodiƒçkova* street and go slightly right hand side => *passage Svƒõtozor* => *Franti≈°k√°nsk√° zahrada* (mentioned in the list), you might continue to *TeTa* passage then across the street *≈†kod≈Øv Pal√°c* (Prague city town hall, btw)

check [https://maps.app.goo.gl/Vdpr3aA87cib34f26](https://maps.app.goo.gl/Vdpr3aA87cib34f26)

At Vinohrady district check *Gr√©bovka  / Havl√≠ƒçkovy sady*

​

And avoid Trdeln√≠k stands , especially kebab version or ice cream version   
\- trdeln√≠k is not traditional Czech, especially not Old-town  origin, as many sellers promote it, and it is usually overpriced (100-150 CZK)

I mostly mean just ordering food, buying things in shops, etc. Will people be able to understand what I'm trying to convey? I did download Google translate but I have never used it so I don't know how effective it will be.

Hi everyone, I'll be in Prague with friends from December 28 2024 to January 1 2025. We‚Äôre thinking about booking a New Year‚Äôs Eve cruise with¬†[Prague Boats](https://www.prague-boats.cz/), which costs around 250 Euros per ticket. It‚Äôs a 4-hour cruise (10 PM - 2 AM) with unlimited beer and wine included.

Has anyone tried this before? Is it worth spending NYE on this cruise, or would you recommend other ways to ring in the New Year in Prague? Thanks in advance for any advice!

comments.author: FromMyLipsToYours
comments.body: I'm visiting for only a few days at the end of March.  As I'm traveling solo, I thought it would be great to get to know a local ahead of time and maybe spend a day together doing things that aren't so touristy.  I'm more into experiencing local culture and not as much about sightseeing though that is not off the list.  Also, volunteering some time while I'm there would be nice.  Any ideas on how to get started? Thanks!

comments.author: SpicedPotatoes
comments.body:
Any advice for a wheelchair user visiting late spring/early summer?   


Any particular phrases or colour coding I should be aware of (for example in Scotland I know I'm looking for "Accessible Entrance" but in Germany I'm looking for "barrierefrei"     


Also related to this, does anyone have any thoughts on general attitude to disabled people they'd be willing to share? I've struggled in the past with small things being different in differnet countries - spent a week being saluted in America because everyone assumed I was a vet, by the end I stopped correcting them. Other countries I've felt like people have been a lot quicker than I'm used to in assuming I can't do things I'm perfectly capable of, and I've had to quickly learn some polite ways of declining help - I'd never want to seem rude or make someone feel bad for trying to help, but in most circumstances I'd rather work out my own solution than be helped towards one.

comments.author: sundaesmilemily
comments.body:
I recommend taking a Taste of Prague food tour. They take you to 4-5 different restaurants and give you history about Czech cuisine. They also give great travel tips and will respond to any questions you have during the rest of your stay. And they share restaurant recommendations on their social media, so even if you don‚Äôt do the tour, they‚Äôre worth following.

https://www.tasteofprague.com

comments.author: wrennox72
comments.body:
This is probably very late but also American here. Verizon you can add "TravelPass" and for every day you're there it'll just trigger $10/day. Or you can pay $100/month. Very convenient and you can use your same phone

edit: there AND use your phone (if you don't need it and turn off roaming, it shouldn't charge you)

comments.author: panda_krtek
comments.body: Depends but the city can be pretty busy as many tourists come to enjoy the xmas period. If you want to explore Prague in a unique way, yet stay in the centre, I recommend playing the game A maze in Prague's passages or the Parks and breathtaking views from Secret City Trails. The passages will still be decorated with xmas lights and trees.

comments.author: LKPSA
comments.body: Hey I live in the Czech Republic and to answer your question simply, I'd say 500-1000 kc per food and drink is enough for each day. You can get great food for less than 200 kc and drinks usually cost around 50 kc, depending on what you get. You want to avoid eating in the main squares since prices are usually higher there. With 1000 kc you can get breakfast, lunch, dinner, drinks, and still have enough for a Trdeln√≠k or something. You can even spend less or more depending on your standards but I'd say 1000 per day is way over enough for everyone (1000 kc is about 40$)

comments.author: Meaxis
comments.body: Honestly, if you're not gonna be calling home and have a modern phone, get an e-sim. o2 offers  e-sims for a month for the whole EU with just enough data to get through your stay. Much worth the $10-90 you'd save

comments.author: Meaxis
comments.body:
Never went to the US but I'd have to pay the [following](https://www.o2.cz/osobni/volani/roaming/spojene-staty-americke):

* $0.17 per ***megabyte*** of data or $12 for 1 GB as package
* $2 per ***minute*** of call ($2.50 if I'm the one placing the call)
* $0.50 for one SMS

In the EU calls and SMS are free according to your tariff and data is around 1/7th of what you normally get in your home country (or 50 GB if you have unlimited)
